However, the Department of Transportation is still constrained by last year’s funding bill and so can’t immediately implement some critical programs in the infrastructure law, which is why it’s so important that we finish the appropriations process as rapidly as possible now.

This legislation is so important for New Jersey because it will finally let us complete the Gateway Project, create thousands of good-paying jobs, revitalize our transit and water infrastructure, and make a down-payment on the green economy.

I was excited this week to join @RepMoulton and @RepJohnKatko in sending a letter to Congressional leadership urging them to quickly complete the FY 2022 appropriations bill so that the Department of Transportation can fully implement the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law.

This legislation is so important for New Jersey because it will finally let us complete the Gateway Project, create thousands of good-paying jobs, revitalize our transit and water infrastructure, and make a down-payment on the green economy.

That’s why a new relief package, targeted at the small businesses most impacted by Omicron, is so critical right now. I won’t stop fighting until we get our communities the relief that they need.

As I’ve met with small business owners and local officials throughout NJ-11, all have expressed concern about the impact of Omicron on our economy and communities. I fear that, without additional assistance, many more businesses in North Jersey will be forced to close.

At the same time, Omicron has greatly impacted consumer demand for businesses centered on in-person gatherings, such as the @MayoCenter in Morristown and so many of our local restaurants, and has made it even more difficult for them to hire the workers they need.

The CARES Act and American Rescue Plan were so important during the pandemic in saving businesses across NJ-11, through  programs like the Paycheck Protection Program and Restaurant Revitalization Fund, but those crucial initiatives have now expired.

This week, I led ten of my colleagues in a letter to President Biden urging the Administration to support and help negotiate a new, targeted relief package to assist small businesses impacted by Omicron.

The COMPETES Act will reduce costs for NJ families & help our businesses better compete with China. I believe on the whole this bill will have a positive impact and I intend to continue working to improve the bill moving forward.

My methane mitigation amendment creates a grant program for states like NJ to offset energy costs for families. It also provides incentives for companies to accelerate and expand improvements to their natural gas distribution systems so we can reduce pollution in our communities.

NIST promotes innovation and competitiveness by advancing measurement science, standards, and tech in ways that enhance economic security. My amendment will strengthen their ability to develop and manage greenhouse gas emissions measurements, which will boost our competitiveness.

And, with that in mind, my amendment investing in long-duration energy storage technology will help us develop new and better ways to increase grid resiliency and reliability so we have less of the power outages North Jersey has come to expect.

NJ needs clean reliable electricity. To this end, I included a provision in this bill that would fund research for rooftop solar & reliable grid tech. We need to support energy innovation at home, not buy from China, to give Americans the affordable, renewable energy of tomorrow.

I was proud to work with @RepTimRyan and @NormaJTorres to ensure the bill creates an expert commission to address supply chain disruptions and establish a supply chain database for our manufacturing sector. These will help us to reduce supply chain problems and prices in NJ.

To combat inflation, I also authored an amendment to help critical supply chain sectors like the trucking and warehouse industries hire and train more workers quickly, by expanding access to our national apprenticeship system.

A top concern that I hear about in NJ-11 is rising prices and inflation. Because of this, I made sure the bill included an amendment requiring the Comptroller General to study and report on how this bill will help to reduce inflation and ensure that funds are spent responsibly.

To that end, after discussing these issues with my constituents, I secured inclusion of several amendments to improve this bill. These amendments focus on some of the most important issues to North Jersey families - cost of living and inflation, renewable energy, and jobs.

This bill is a strong step in the right direction. Moving forward, I remain committed to working to ensure the final version of this legislation does everything possible to lower costs for NJ families.

On Friday, I was proud to vote for the America COMPETES Act, which will help strengthen our supply chain and reduce inflation, increase our competitiveness with China, and bolster R&D initiatives that are critical to innovation and GDP growth.

Iran is one of the largest state sponsors of terrorism, has created insecurity throughout the Middle East, and presents an existential threat to Israel. I remain committed to ensuring the US takes appropriate diplomatic action to prevent a nuclear Iran.
This week’s Senate floor debate further illustrates the need for US efforts to ensure Iran does not have a path to developing nuclear weapons.

I am hopeful we can ensure a final bill continues to benefit American manufacturing, support workers throughout the nation, advance the clean energy economy, and help to end America’s dependency on key technologies like semiconductors.
I will continue to work to ensure the final version does everything possible to lower inflation for NJ families. I successfully secured passage of seven amendments to improve the legislation.
This bill will also increase our competitiveness with China, and fund the R&D initiatives that are so important to innovation, economic growth, and clean energy development in New Jersey.

COMPETES also aims to remedy the vulnerabilities in America’s supply chain that have often made us dependent on rival nations for key goods, and will bolster the size and skill level of our STEM workforce.

Today, we took a major step towards curbing inflation, stopping the rise in prices for goods like groceries and gas, and addressing disruptions in our supply chain by passing in the House the America COMPETES Act of 2022.https://t.co/MWDQZi6f1K

Yet, they often do not have the same access to GI Bill benefits that other servicemembers do. In the House, we passed the Guard and Reserve GI Bill Parity Act, which will achieve parity in education benefits and ensure #EveryDayInUniformCounts. https://t.co/t8udAIB0Wp

Over the past two years, our National Guard and Reserve Members have been on the frontlines of our response to the COVID-19 pandemic, protecting our Capitol after Jan 6, and playing a key role in our drawdown from Afghanistan.

The right to vote and elect our own leaders is a sacred part of what it means to be an American, and this legislation demonstrates our commitment to uphold these ideals. I strongly urge the Senate to now pass this bill immediately.

This legislation takes steps to stop politicians that seek to interfere with or refuse to certify dutifully cast ballots by creating a new right to vote legal standard, preventing election officials from being removed for political reasons, and expanding protections for ballots.

This legislation will also bolster opportunities to vote by expanding early voting and vote-by-mail, end extreme gerrymandering by creating new neutral redistricting standards, and expand voter registration by increasing automatic, same-day, and online registration efforts.

The bill we passed today would create a new federal preclearance requirement that will ensure that states cannot pass election reforms that discriminate against certain Americans. That provision is the central component of the John Lewis Voting Rights Act.

It was the decision to strike down critical pieces of the Voting Rights Act in 2013 that has allowed these states to chip away at our democracy and has made it very difficult to fight against state voting laws that are riddled with discrimination.

As January 6 showed, democracy faces critical risks across the nation. The integrity of our elections is being endangered by officials in states who care more about partisan wins than preserving democracy & dozens of states have passed new laws restricting voting opportunities.

Today, the House voted on a major voting rights bill, which will protect the fundamental rights of Americans to vote and have their voices heard by enacting key provisions of the Freedom to Vote Act and the John Lewis Voting Rights Act. https://t.co/ZD76B0yJ7j

I have conflicting emotions about Jan 6. Yes, it marks one of the darkest days in our nation's history. But the brave acts of so many people that day & in the days that followed, fill me w/ hope that we can begin to heal as a nation & become a stronger, more resilient democracy. https://t.co/MKDOrITOFQ

I’m a mom of four kids. I want them to have the same freedoms and protections, the same opportunities and say in their government that we have had. So today, as we commemorate and reflect, it’s their future that I’m thinking about most.

Today, as we remember what happened, our focus should be on what we can and need to do to ensure an attack like that never happens again. It’s our duty now to do everything in our power to safeguard our American values and freedoms.
January 6 marked a dark day in our democracy. But it does not and will not define us.

I could have never imagined living up to that oath would one day mean protecting our democracy from fellow Americans or a former president who sought to undermine our elections in an attempt to stay in power.

When I repeated those words, the images of the Nazis my grandfather fought during World War II or the armies of the Soviet Union I saw growing up during the Cold War were the ones that populated my mind.
That oath bestows the responsibility to support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign or domestic.

I’ve taken that oath many times. The first when I was 18 years old entering the US Naval Academy, excited and proud to serve our nation. Since then, I’ve taken it throughout my Naval career, at the US Attorney’s Office, and, now, as your Congresswoman.

Today, I want to share some reflections I have on the one year anniversary of that attack.

On that day, and in the year after it, my mind turned to two things: my family and my oath to the Constitution.

On January 6, 2021, I stood in the House Gallery as an angry mob, sent by the President of the United States, stormed the Capitol building with the intention of preventing Congress from carrying out the will of the people and certifying our election.

The investments made in the bipartisan infrastructure law will create jobs, combat the climate crisis, and lower public health costs. That all serves to make New Jersey safer, healthier, and stronger for decades to come. https://t.co/uWMNFmO6Jy
